importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article's publication marks the public announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, signaling a major advancement in the nation's space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe indicates that Pakistan's space programme has seen rapid development in 2025, with three satellites launched in the same year, highlighting a strategic push toward self-reliance in space technology.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space programme.
The H1 satellite was launched from China's Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral technology allows detection of subtle chemical and material changes on Earth, enabling applications in agriculture, environmental monitoring, disaster management, and urban planning.
The satellite is expected to improve precision agriculture, climate resilience, and resource management in Pakistan.
The launch reflects a deepening strategic partnership between Pakistan and China in peaceful space exploration.
The satellite is part of a broader effort by Pakistan to strengthen its space capabilities, with two other operational satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) already in orbit.
Full operational status of H1 is expected within about two months, following system calibration.
The mission supports national development goals, including the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), by enhancing geohazard risk identification and infrastructure planning.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China's Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a major milestone in its space programme. The satellite, capable of detecting subtle material changes on Earth, will support national priorities such as precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, disaster response, and urban planning. This achievement underscores Pakistan’s growing technological capabilities and deepening strategic cooperation with China, particularly in the context of infrastructure development like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While full operational status is expected within two months, the mission reflects a broader trend of Pakistan launching multiple satellites in 2025, with two others (EO-1 and KS-1) already in orbit. The launch is hailed as a critical step in advancing national development and self-reliance in space technology.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
